Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: My phone buzzed with a text from my brother: “Can you come over? I really need to talk.” I could hear the heaviness in his words, the kind that only comes when he’s truly struggling. As his sister, I’ve always promised to be there, especially when he’s hurting. But just as I was grabbing my keys, my phone rang again—this time, it was the synagogue coordinator. They needed one more person for the minyan to say Kaddish at a funeral. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen, and the grieving family would be left without the comfort of tradition. My heart twisted. My brother needed me, but so did my community. I stood in the hallway, torn between the pull of family and the call of faith, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
